properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: "Arrowheads"

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Relevance to mission statement
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: 44RN21-Graham White dig

properties.Repository Name: Eastern Shore of Virginia Historical Society (ESVHS), Ker Place
properties.ShortName: Eastern Shore of Virginia Historical Society (ESVHS), Ker Place
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only those recovered from the Ker Place property
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: All-for understanding Federal Period life and decorative arts

properties.Secondary Contact Person: Douglas K. Harvey- Museum System Director
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Available room and significance
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: One archaeological collection that was dug at Point of Honor- a Federal era plantation mansion built by Dr. George Cabell in 1815.  Several digs have been performed at the site to locate remains of outbuildings- etc.  While many artifacts have been dug- very few constitute significant finds.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Mostly items of local interest- archaeological and historical artifacts- especially those relating to the Mecklenburg Hotel and the Thyne Institute.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: The Arthur G. Robertson Collection (44X32) consists of approximately 44 standard size Hollinger boxes of prehistoric artifacts (35 of lithics and 9 of ceramics) and numerous frames of stone implements from Virginia and other states.  Many artifacts from this collection are on display at MMMG and in the projectile point spread created by K. Egloff in the Virginia Historical Society's Story of Virginia exhibit.

properties.Contact Person: Robert Teagle- Education Director and Curator
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only those related to historic Christ Church
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We believe our collections are significant in their potential to contribute towards the study of one of America's most significant colonial landscapes- and particularly the architecture of the standing church (ca. 1732) and the 17th-and 18th-century surroundings of this building and its predecessor- built ca. 1670.  Our emphasis has been the consistent recovery of material from all periods of occupation

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only those related to the historic plantation- Menokin
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We believe our collections are significant in their potential to contribute towards the study of plantation life throughout the historic period.  Our emphasis has been the consistent recovery of material from all periods of occupation.  We are nearing completion of an evaluation of our collections and a synthesis of prior excavations in GIS

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only those related to the historic plantation- Rosewell.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We believe our collections are significant in their potential to contribute towards the study of plantation life throughout the historic period.  Our emphasis has been the consistent recovery of materials from all periods of excavation.

properties.Building: Department of Anthropology College of William & Mary
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only those related to Werowocomoco
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We believe these collections are significant in their potential to contribute towards the study of a contentious period of our shared heritage (1607-1609) while also providing insight into the long history of Virginia Indians that lived on the site as far back as the Archaic period.  In addition- the collection includes significant colonial material culture from subsequent occupations from the mid-17th century through the early 20th century.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you highlight to: Material related to Virginia Indians and contentious period of our shared heritage (1607-1609)

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
N/A
New collections are accepted as gifts or loans.  Loans may be indefinite or for a specified period.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Archival holdings

properties.Repository Name: Cape Charles Museum and Welcome Center
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Pertinent to local history
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Old photographs
The Strode Collection

properties.Contact Person: Georgette N. Hurley- Assistant County Administrator
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Any requests are evaluated on a case-by-case basis
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Many of the collections have significant research potential- including artifacts from the Debtor's Jail and other projects around the historic courthouse- the Free School Excavation- the Gloucester Town dump- and the Owl Trap collection.  In addition- they could be of greater use in answering research questions related to the development of colonial towns and courthouse villages- 19th-century rural lifeways and mortuary information- and the introduction of Methodism (Owl Trap) to Virginia

properties.Contact Person: Judy Hynson- Director of Research and Library Collections
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Based on the collection policy in CMP
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: The artifact collection from the 17th century Clifts "Manner House" has contributed much information about the social history on the early Northern Neck settlers.  Artifacts from Stratford's Orchard Site (ST116)- which contained a late 18th-century earthfast slave dwelling- have been entered into the DAACS database.  We are seeking funding for putting the artifact collection from the ongoing excavation of the Oval Site into DAACS; this is a domestic complex of mostly earthfast structures (4 so far) that may possibly include a dwelling- barn- and associated quarter.  We highlight these three because they provide us with information about the enslaved and other working occupants of the plantation who were not as well represented in the documentary records of the Lee owners

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Uncertain of any significance

properties.Repository Name: Newton History Center of The Stone House Foundation
properties.ShortName: Newton History Center of The Stone House Foundation
properties.Secondary Contact Person: Wayne Eldred- Collections and Programs Manager
properties.Building: Newton History Center of The Stone House Foundation
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Donation- Museum Purchase
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Wagons- diaries- newspaper- furniture- fine craftsmanship and cottage industry before railroad and mass production

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Relates to Culpeper or its immediate region; has some relation to the present theme of study (i.e. 150th anniversary of the American Civil War)
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We had objects that relate to many themes relating to Culpeper: Dinosaurs- Native Americans (projectile points- tools- weapons- etc.)- natural history (fossils- shark's teeth)- material culture items such as weapons- textiles- tools- medical implements- art- photograph.  African-American items relating to slavery- emancipation- freedmen- agriculture- Jim Crow laws- prominent blacks in Culpeper.  Our Civil War collection was the initial acquisition (1975+); we have many objects and memorabilia relating to Culpeper's role in the war.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Materials excavated on property
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: 44AX3C

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: New materials recovered from the Monitor National Marine Sanctuary are added to the collection
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Both of the archaeological collections we maintain have significant bearing on Virginia history.  The Ronson ship is the only surviving example of a vessel built in colonial Virginia.  Unfortunately- while the bow is stable it is not in a form that is easily viewable nor is it in an area where it can be easily brought to the attention of the public.  The USS Monitor Collection is tangentially related to Virginia History (the famous battle of Hampton Roads- the first naval battle fought between ironclad ships- occurred in Virginia)
properties.Q6 Which collections do you highlight to: The USS Monitor Collection is consistently highlighted to donors- researchers- the general public- and legislators
properties.Comments: The Museum also holds a number of items that were salvaged from the York River in the 1930s.  There aren't any associated archaeological records.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: All
properties.Comments: Many reports of investigations since 2000 w/art collections- 1 cataloged collection~2001-2002- 1960s report

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only material excavated at Gunston Hall
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Gunston Hall- also has a large collection of archival material and historic objects- as well as mid-18th century mansion which belonged to one of the founding fathers sitting on 55 acres of the original plantation.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: All artifacts in the collection have research potential- we highlight prehistoric- early colonial- Washington Family- Civil War- and commemorative artifacts

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Collections made during fieldwork at Monticello or on other properties owned by the Thomas Jefferson Foundation
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We have three groups that are probably more historically significant than our others.  First- we have a robust archaeological collection from Mulberry Row- a street of workshops and houses for enslaved and free laborers- artisans- and domestics.  This collections spans the entire period of Monticello's operation and beyond.  Second- we have a growing collection from enslaved and overseer domestic sites located near the agricultural fields of Monticello Plantation. Third- we house the entire archaeological collection from Shadwell- Thomas Jefferson's child home and a quarter farm during the operation of Monticello Plantation.

properties.Repository Name: Virginia Archaeological Resource Center of the ASV (also Kittiewan Chapter)
properties.ShortName: Virginia Archaeological Resource Center of the ASV (also Kittiewan Chapter)
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: At present- consensus of ASV Board of Directors (pending re-establishment of ASV Collections Committee)
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Significance of most collections remains undetermined at this time.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Must be relevant to scope of collection.  For archaeology- no unscientifically excavated materials
properties.Q6 Which collections do you highlight to: Historical collections for Manassas and Prince William County History- Civil War collections for national audience- Archives of Civil War material and local material and VDHR surveys for general researchers and historic preservationists- For teachers- highlight subjects in SOL related topics- Do not highlight any archaeological collections

properties.Q5 When are they available?: By appointment on a case-by-case basis

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Objects excavated form the property- collections donated by relic hunters who frequented the property in pre-Trust days (pre 1984)
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Madison-era occupation of Montpelier including slave sites- midden deposits from the two generations of Madison tables- and the extensive collection of objects from our Civil War sites

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: How they relate to the mission of the museum
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: The Basse's Choice collection is the most thoroughly researched and cataloged.  The story as it relates to the early settlement of the James River region and is of great interest to the public and historians.

properties.Repository Name: Historic Services Department, City of Newport News
properties.ShortName: Historic Services Department, City of Newport News
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Depends on historical as well as local significance.  Condition and size do play a part in the decision
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We feel every artifact has the potential to contribute to the history of the area.  Our archaeological collections for the Historic Houses of Lee Hall and Endview are the most expansive.  We house the artifacts from the archaeological investigations at Warwicktowne (44NN69- 44NN278)

properties.Building: The Corporation for Jefferson's Poplar Forest
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: All periods and all types of sites
properties.Q6 Which collections do you highlight to: Jefferson period landscape- public-mostly Jefferson period including slavery

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: All of these collections have research potential. Many contain slave related artifacts-some prehistoric artifacts from important sites

properties.Contact Person: Dr. C. Cliff Boyd- Professor of Anthropology
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: If they have fairly decent contextual information- if they were legally obtained- and if they would be useful in student instruction.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: The ceramics from several Late Woodland sites in Smyth and Montgomery Counties- 44MY1- 44MY3- 44MY37- and 44SM25- and 44SM31 The lithics from three Archaic sites in Floyd County- 44FD57- 44FD58- and 44FD61

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only archaeological material collected on park property
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: The Henry Brooks collection and the John Washington collection in regards to early Virginia history.  Early 18th century with Augustine Washington/Austin Washington site.  The John Washington site could contribute depth to a Washington family plantation study.

properties.Repository Name: University of Virginia Library Harrison Institute of American History, Literature, and Culture
properties.Q5 When are they available?: By appointment- open to the public for research and Uva faculty and students
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Study- surface- and small finds- and museum exhibit collections are highlighted since they touch on areas of settlement patterns- cultural change through time- and adaptation and innovation from Paleo-Contact through the 19th century
properties.Q6 Which collections do you highlight to: Study- surface- and small finds- and museum exhibit collections are highlighted since they touch on areas of settlement patterns- cultural change through time- and adaptation and innovation from Paleo-Contact through the 19th century

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: As long as they are up to standards and from federal entities.  If the new collections are not up to standards- depositors can pay to have the collections prepared for curation by our staff.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Here at the RACF we house over 300 boxes of artifacts totaling over one half million individual artifacts.  Many of the military installations whose artifacts we house are located in areas that have a rich archaeological history.  The sites we house range from early prehistoric camps to small domestic remains from the early 20th century.  Fort Lee's collection with the exception of two sites- 44PG316 and 44PG317 have not been extensively studied making the research potential high.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Continually accessioning those from Mount Vernon's ongoing archaeology program.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We highlight the overall Historic Mount Vernon site (44FX762 and 44FX763) the most- as well as the distillery (44FX2262). Because there are so many specific areas within the 44FX762 and 763 site numbers- we highlight the House For Families slave quarter (762/40-47)- the South Grove trash midden (762/17)- the Upper Garden (762/43)- blacksmiths shop (762/12)- dung repository (762/15) and the orchard (763/4) as those with the most research potential.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: When they are from Prince William County, VA and considered important. Often proffered with county zoning.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We have more than 150 collections, and I couldn't specify just one.

properties.Repository Name: Jamestown Settlement and Yorktown Victory Center
properties.ShortName: Jamestown Settlement and Yorktown Victory Center
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Jamestown's English origins, the early colonial period, the American Indian culture of southeastern Virginia and the African culture that arrived in Virginia in the 17th century, the American Revolution era, and the early years of the new nation.
properties.Q7 How many archaeological collections d: 179,000 archaeological artifacts at Jamestown Settlement and 1,270 at Yorktown Victory Center

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: From Fairfax County
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Those resulting from Phase II data recoveries- those with documentation- we house collections from the following agencies for projects in Fairfax County: Bureau of Land Management- Fish and Wildlife- Virginia State Parks- Northern Virginia Regional Park Authority- Fort Belvoir.  We have collections from long-term projects such as Sully Historic Site- Mount Air- and many other projects which have been derived from National Register eligible or listed sites that highlight Virginia history.
properties.Q7 How many archaeological collections d: 3 million artifacts from ~3600 sites stored in ~1000 boxes

properties.Repository Name: USDA Forest Service-George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only collections excavated on George Washington and Jefferson National Forest land
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Late Woodland/Contact period site Keyser Farm (44PA1)  This collection is on loan at the DHR and currently accessible to researchers.
properties.Q7 How many archaeological collections d: 3,000 sites on record of which at least half have artifacts from Late Archaic to 20th century.  284 cubic feet of collections

properties.Repository Name: Virginia National Guard Artifact Curation Facility (Fort Pickett)
properties.ShortName: Virginia National Guard Artifact Curation Facility/Ft. Picket
properties.Building: Virginia Army National Guard- VAFM-E Building 316- Fort Pickett
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Everything collected during NHPA Section 106/110 activities sponsored by the VA Army Guard and all inadvertent discoveries on Fort Pickett or other VA Army Guard Facilities
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: There are currently 70-855 federally-owned objects in the collection from 313 sites from Brunswick- Dinwiddie- and Nottoway Counties.  The majority represent prehistoric campsites from the Archaic and Woodland periods.  Historic sites are primarily 19th and 20th centuries.  There are also several mill sites and cemeteries.
properties.Comments: There are currently 77 boxes of artifacts and 4 oversized objects in the collection.  All collections have associated paper records and photos and most have associated electronic records and images.  We also house associated documents and photos for architectural survey projects which have no artifacts.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: In theory only those related to Alexandria- but Code work is accepted on a case by case basis although it is eventually required to go to an "appropriate" facility
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Pottery sites- Sugar House- Urban African-American sites- Market Square Area-shaft feature
properties.Q6 Which collections do you highlight to: Pottery sites- Sugar House- Urban African-American sites- Market Square Area-shaft feature
properties.Q7 How many archaeological collections d: 3300 Cu feet of OHA and Alexandria sites

properties.Contact Person: Emily Williams- Conservator of Archaeological Materials
properties.Building: Department of Conservation Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: New materials from Colonial Williamsburg's excavations are accepted as they are excavated.  Material from other archaeological sites is not added to the collection.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: The archaeological collection is the result of nearly 80 years of excavation in Colonial Williamsburg's Historic Area and its immediate surrounds.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you highlight to: Because of the collection's breadth- no one set of objects is highlighted for donors- the public or other visitors.  Different selections are made depending on the object's ability to inform the current research questions or the donor's/visitor's interests.
properties.Q7 How many archaeological collections d: 80 years of research and 60 million artifacts

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Per collections policy and committee review
properties.Q5 When are they available?: Very limited basis to qualified professionals for research
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Don't know
properties.Q7 How many archaeological collections d: 86 boxes with 39 identifiable collections and a variety of other miscellaneous material

properties.Street Address: Dept. of Sociology and Anthropology- MSC 7501 Sheldon Hall- 800 S. Main St.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
Associated with 106 projects on the VIMS campus
properties.Q5 When are they available?: By appointment at DHR- not at all at VIMS
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: All collections related to excavations at Gloucestertown are significant in their potential to contribute towards the study of numerous themes associated with the prehistoric and historic periods.  A small sample of these include 18th-century urbanism- Revolutionary War and Civil War fortifications- and Early Woodlands encampments.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you highlight to: Efforts to synthesize over 40 years of excavations (salvage- survey- or full-scale mitigation in areas of proposed impact for building or infrastructure construction related to the campus) highlights the value of the collection
properties.Comments: Collections are held at VIMS and DHR- it is possible that the material at VIMS will be transferred to DHR

properties.Building: Department of Anthropology College of William & Mary
properties.Comments: collections amassed by Norm Barka and Ted Reinhart through contract or research archaeology; for much of Barka s stuff- they have everything but the artifacts and final reports

properties.Building: Department of Sociology and Anthropology- Washington and Lee University
properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Only exceptions would be collections created through the university's spring archaeological dig classes- and extraordinary circumstances
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: Rockbridge- campus archaeology of Washington and Lee-Liberty Hall excavations and main campus excavations- industrial mining communities of the 19th and early 20th centuries-Longsdale Mining Community- and the historic pottery industry of the Valley

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: N/A
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: The collection's research potential has yet to be established
properties.Comments: Closing 2011 and collections are transferring to Fort Lee

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Depending on what they are- on how much room they will need- we take into consideration what the donor wants for the collection
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We have a large display case of artifacts that were taken from sites in Henry County- Virginia during the 1970s.  The artifacts are not specified as to which site-  All are surface finds.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: Based on the collection policy. In general, we accept all archaeological collection from Virginia that have research value (i.e., usually not personal collections with no provenience). We also accept collections that are from non-Virginia locations as part of our mission to interpret Virginia's natural history in a global context.
properties.Q6 Which collections do you believe cont: We have a variety of collections from the state. Two of our more recent acquisitions are large assemblages from large surveys done by Dr. William Gardner in the 1970s. This 130+ boxes of material has the potential to yield additional information about settlement pattern, ceramics types and seriation, use of exotic vs. local lithic materials, etc. The Hurt Power Plant site assemblage represents an extensive collection of materials from a major Native American trade network site. The Brook Run site assemblage of lithics from a jasper quarry has potential to examine questions about lithic tool production. We also have many other assemblages from prehistoric and historic sites.

properties.Q3 What is your basis for accepting arch: That they be from Virginia and meet other criteria.  Box fees payable for care and management in perpetuity.

properties.Comments: Currently- these collections are at Fort Lee for cataloging.
